required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Rescue Quadratus Lumborum Blocks for Post-cesarean Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Rescue Quadratus Lumborum Blocks for Post-cesarean Pain

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to see whether or not quadratus lumborum (QL) blocks performed on post-operative day 1 will provide supplemental post-cesarean analgesia and reduce opioid requirements.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amount of opioids used
Amount of opioids used

time from quadratus lumborum block until first opioid request
secondary_outcome.time_frame: time of first opioid use after QL block is done(upto 96 hours)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain as measured by the 11 point verbal pain score at rest and with movement at each time point
secondary_outcome.time_frame: time of (quadratus lumborum) QL block (one day following cesarean delivery)
secondary_outcome.description: This is measured form 0-10 higher number indicating a worse pain

intervention.description: patients in the control group will not receive quadratus lumborum blocks and will be evaluated on post-operative day 2 and offered quadratus lumborum blocks if their pain remains >5/10 - however they will be dropped from the study if they undergo quadratus lumborum blocks.
Patients will receive quadratus lumborum blocks with 20ml 0.25% bupivacaine (50mg), 3mg preservative-free dexamethasone, and 10ml 0.9% saline once on each side.
Patients will receive quadratus lumborum blocks with a mixture of 10ml 0.25% bupivacaine (25mg), 10ml liposomal bupivacaine (133mg), and 10ml 0.9% saline once on each side.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- elective or non-elective cesarean delivery on prior day
- pain scores >5/10
Exclusion Criteria:
- BMI >40
- obstructive sleep apnea
- drug abuse
- chronic pain
- chronic opioid use
- abdominal surgeries other than cesarean delivery
- contraindications to neuraxial or regional anesthesia
- received general anesthesia or did not receive neuraxial morphine for cesarean delivery
